literature_search.user: Find recent research papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus.
literature_search.ai_response:
I'll search recent literature on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus (returning top relevant papers). I'll fetch 7 results.## Recent research papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus

I searched recent literature and found several relevant reviews and primary papers (2021–2025) that focus on hippocampal synaptic plasticity, mechanisms (LTP/LTD/BTSP), interneuron plasticity, and links to behavior/pathology. Below I list the most relevant items returned by the literature search tool with brief summaries and links. If you want, I can attempt to retrieve full texts for any of these using the read-paper tool.

---

### 1) The Intriguing Contribution of Hippocampal Long-Term Depression to Spatial Learning and Long-Term Memory  
- **Authors:** Martin Stacho, Denise Manahan-Vaughan  
- **Published:** 25 April 2022 (Frontiers in Behavioral Neuroscience)  
- **DOI / Link:** https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnbeh.2022.806356/pdf  
- **Summary:** Review focusing on hippocampal LTD (long-term depression) and its distinct roles—beyond being simply the counterpart to LTP—in spatial learning, memory retention of details, synaptic pruning of excitatory spines, and pattern separation. Discusses behavioral-electrophysiological evidence from rodents and the interplay between structural spine changes and LTP/LTD.  

---

### 2) Interplay of epilepsy and long-term potentiation: implications for memory  
- **Authors:** Luis A. Marin-Castañeda et al.  
- **Published:** 10 January 2025 (Frontiers in Neuroscience)  
- **DOI / Link:** https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/neuroscience/articles/10.3389/fnins.2024.1451740/full  
- **Image:**  
  ![Frontiers figure image](https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=1200&f=png/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/Articles/1451740/fnins-18-1451740-HTML/image_m/fnins-18-1451740-g001.jpg)  
- **Summary:** Review addressing how dysregulation of LTP/LTD mechanisms and neuroinflammation link to epilepsy and memory dysfunction. Examines signaling pathways (MAPK, mTOR, WNT/β-catenin), calcium signaling, and how aberrant plasticity contributes to hyperexcitability and cognitive effects.

---

### 3) Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons  
- **Authors:** Kevin C. Gonzalez, Adrian Negrean, Zhenrui Liao, Satoshi Terada, et al. (Attila Losonczy lab among authors)  
- **Published:** 18 December 2024 (Nature)  
- **DOI / Link:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9  
- **Image:**  
  ![Nature figure image](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Summary:** Primary research describing an all-optical approach to monitor synaptic tuning and plasticity at single-neuron resolution in awake behaving animals. Investigates how synaptic plasticity underlies place-field formation and feature selectivity in hippocampal CA1 neurons.

---

### 4) Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus  
- **Authors:** Sachin P. Vaidya, Guanchun Li, Raymond A. Chitwood, Yiding Li, Jeffrey C. Magee, et al.  
- **Published:** 04 June 2025 (Nature Neuroscience)  
- **DOI / Link:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3  
- **Image:**  
  ![Nature Neuroscience figure image](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Summary:** Tracks CA1 place cells across days of learning; shows progressive stabilization of place-cell populations and links this to behavioral-timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP). Suggests memory encoding emerges through increased likelihood of neuron-specific plasticity across sessions rather than simple long-term stabilization of synaptic weights.

---

### 5) Synaptic plasticity and mental health: methods, challenges and opportunities  
- **Authors:** Lawrence G. Appelbaum, Mohammad Ali Shenasa, Louise Stolz, Zafiris Daskalakis  
- **Published:** 2022 (Neuropsychopharmacology / Nature partner journal) — review article (PDF returned)  
- **DOI / Link (PDF):** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41386-022-01370-w.pdf?error=cookies_not_supported&code=34e16863-ac9f-4f45-8219-2ce69826f3af  
- **Summary:** Broad review of synaptic plasticity mechanisms, imaging/methodological approaches to study plasticity (including in humans), and implications for psychiatric disorders. Discusses measurement challenges and translational opportunities.

---

### 6) Hippocampal Somatostatin Interneurons, Long-Term Synaptic Plasticity and Memory  
- **Authors:** Maria Gutierrez-Mecinas et al.  
- **Published:** 02 June 2021 (Frontiers in Neural Circuits)  
- **DOI / Link:** https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fncir.2021.687558/full  
- **Image:**  
  ![Frontiers figure image](https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=1200&f=png/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/Articles/687558/fncir-15-687558-HTML/image_m/fncir-15-687558-g0001.jpg)  
- **Summary:** Review focused on SOM (somatostatin-expressing) interneurons in hippocampus: their synaptic plasticity at excitatory synapses, induction/expression mechanisms, metaplastic regulation of hippocampal networks, and implications for learning and disease (e.g., Alzheimer’s models).

---

### 7) Editorial: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity at hippocampal and cortical synapses  
- **Authors:** Nathalia Vitureira, Roberto De Pasquale, Ricardo M. Leão, Francesco Mattia Rossi (editors)  
- **Published:** 15 July 2022 (Frontiers in Cellular Neuroscience)  
- **DOI / Link:** https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fncel.2022.980623/pdf  
- **Summary:** Editorial introducing a Research Topic collection on mechanisms of synaptic plasticity (LTP, LTD, HSP, STDP) at hippocampal and cortical synapses — useful pointer to multiple focused articles in the collection.

---

## Next steps (pick any)
- I can fetch full-text PDFs for any of these items (use the read-paper tool) — tell me which paper(s).  
- I can search for more recent primary experimental papers (e.g., specific to CA1 LTP mechanisms, NMDA vs. CaMKII, or BTSP) or expand to pre-2021 classic references.  
- I can create a short annotated bibliography (1–2 paragraph summaries + key methods/findings) for whichever items you want prioritized.

web_search.user: Search the web for information about NEURON simulation software.
web_search.ai_response:
I'll search the web for information about the NEURON simulation software and return key resources and summaries.## Web search summary — NEURON simulation software

Let me summarize key resources and practical information found on the web about the **NEURON** simulator.

![NEURON overview screenshot](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/_images/neuron-overview.jpg)

### Quick description
- **NEURON** — a widely used simulation environment for modeling individual neurons and networks of neurons. It emphasizes biologically realistic, morphologically detailed cells and provides interfaces for HOC, Python, and a GUI.  
  Source: [NEURON documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/) and [NEURON (Yale) site](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/).

---

## Key resources (official)

- **Documentation / Guides**
  - [The NEURON Simulator — Documentation](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/) — comprehensive docs, installation, programmer’s reference, guides and examples.
  - [Guides and Tutorials (NEURON site)](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/docs) — tutorials for beginners, GUI tools (CellBuilder, Import3D, Channel Builder), Python use, and advanced topics.

- **Official project site / community**
  - [NEURON (Yale) main page](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/) — project announcements, downloads, forum links, course info, ModelDB references.

- **Getting started / installation**
  - “How to get started” guide: [How to get started with NEURON — nrn.readthedocs.io](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/how_to_get_started.html) — recommended install commands (pip: `pip install neuron`), platform-specific notes, using MPI for parallel runs, and pointers to forum and tutorials.

---

## Important features & notes

- Purpose-built for neuroscience: optimized solvers and data structures for branched neuron morphologies and membrane mechanisms; intended to let users focus on biological questions rather than low-level numerical details. (See: [What is NEURON?](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/neuron/what_is_neuron))

- Interfaces:
  - Scripting via **Python** (recommended) and legacy **HOC**.
  - Rich GUI tools for model construction: **CellBuilder**, **ChannelBuilder**, **Import3D**, **Network Builder**.
  - Integrates ModelDB model repository for example models.

- Extending NEURON:
  - **NMODL**: language for user-defined mechanisms (ion channels, pumps, ion accumulation). Important note: starting with NEURON ≥ 9.0, NMODL compiles to C++ (not C), so older mod files may need adaptation. Documentation contains guidance: [Adapting MOD files for C++ with NEURON ≥ 9.0](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/).

- Parallel & cloud:
  - NEURON supports MPI-based parallel simulations and runs on local machines, cloud notebooks (e.g., Google Colab via `pip install neuron`), and HPC resources (Neuroscience Gateway, EBRAINS).

- Learning resources:
  - Recorded NEURON courses and exercises (linked from docs).
  - NEURON Forum for installation help, model questions, and community discussion.

---

## Practical starting steps (concise)

1. Read the “How to get started” guide: [nrn.readthedocs.io — How to get started](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/how_to_get_started.html).
2. Install NEURON:
   - Linux/macOS: `pip install neuron`
   - Windows: use the Windows installer from the NEURON site (or use WSL + pip).
3. Try tutorials from the docs and the GUI tools (CellBuilder, Import3D).
4. Browse ModelDB for example models to adapt.
5. For custom mechanisms, read the NMODL guidance and the notes on adapting older mod files for NEURON ≥ 9.0.
6. Join the NEURON Forum for community support.

---

## Useful links (official)
- [NEURON documentation (nrn.readthedocs.io)](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/)  
- [NEURON main site — Yale](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/)  
- [Guides and tutorials](https://neuron.yale.edu/neuron/docs)  
- [How to get started](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/how_to_get_started.html)  
- [What is NEURON?](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/neuron/what_is_neuron)

---

If you want, I can:
- Retrieve specific tutorial pages (examples: Python scripting, CellBuilder tutorial).
- Find ModelDB models for a cell type of interest.
- Search for papers demonstrating NEURON-based studies.
Which of these would you like next?

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
```

## Simulation Costs

Simulation costs depend on your plan (Free or Pro) and the type of simulation you're running.

### Simulation Costs by Plan

| Simulation Type | Free Plan | Pro Plan |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|
| **E-model** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Ion channel** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Single cell** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Synaptome** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Small microcircuit** (≤10 neurons) | 10 credits/simulation | 5 credits/simulation |
| **Microcircuit** (>10 neurons) | 0.05 credits/neuron/second of biological time | 0.025 credits/neuron/second of biological time |

### Credits Included

- **Free Plan:** 100 free initial credits (expire in 1 year)
- **Pro Plan Monthly:** 50 free credits/month (CHF 25/month)
- **Pro Plan Yearly:** 650 free credits/year (CHF 275/year)

### Cost Savings with Pro

The Pro plan offers approximately **50% cost reduction** on all simulation types:
- Basic simulations: 0.5 vs 1 credit
- Small microcircuits: 5 vs 10 credits
- Large microcircuits: Half the per-neuron cost

### Example Calculations

- **10 single cell simulations on Free:** 10 credits
- **10 single cell simulations on Pro:** 5 credits
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Free:** 5 credits (100 × 0.05)
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Pro:** 2.5 credits (100 × 0.025)

Source: OBI pricing plans (Sanity planV2).

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
I'll search recent literature for studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum.Let me summarize recent, relevant studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum (cortex / forebrain) and provide links and short descriptions. I searched recent literature for cortical/cerebrum neuron morphology papers and selected representative studies (2023–2026).

## Recent studies (selected)

### 1. **An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex** (2025)
- **Published:** 09 April 2025 — Nature Communications  
- **Link:** [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w)  
- **Summary:** Large-scale, unsupervised mapping of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in mouse visual cortex; presents an atlas-like organization of dendritic types using data-driven clustering approaches.  
- **Figure (from paper):**  
  ![Dendritic morphology summary figure](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2. **Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry** (2024)
- **Published:** 26 November 2024 — Nature Communications  
- **Link:** [Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6?error=cookies_not_supported&code=9de490d8-2096-42e3-a5d6-bcf63bd6ac17)  
- **Summary:** Whole-brain morphometry examining neuronal diversity and stereotyped features across regions; relevant for understanding how cerebral (cortical) neuron morphologies vary across scales and regions.  
- **Figure (from paper):**  
  ![Whole-brain morphometry figure](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3. **Single-neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex** (2023)
- **Published:** 22 May 2023 — Nature Neuroscience  
- **Link:** [Single-neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01339-y?error=cookies_not_supported&code=473b0b6a-f6a9-45f3-a4eb-fc499b0481aa)  
- **Summary:** Complete dendrite and axon reconstructions for ~2,000 neurons in mouse prefrontal cortex (PFC). Identifies many dendritic subtypes and relates somatodendritic scaling to cytoarchitecture; links morphology to potential connectivity patterns and electrophysiological phenotypes.  
- **Figure (from paper):**  
  ![PFC single-neuron reconstructions](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-023-01339-y/MediaObjects/41593_2023_1339_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 4. **Cell class–specific long-range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker-related somatosensory cortices** (2024, eLife)
- **Published:** Reviewed preprint / Version of Record Oct 11, 2024 — eLife  
- **Link:** [Cell class–specific long-range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker-related somatosensory cortices (eLife)](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/97602)  
- **Summary:** Detailed mapping of layer- and class-specific long-range axonal outputs from somatosensory (barrel/whisker) cortex. Uses genetic targeting and whole-cell reconstructions; relevant for how cortical neuron classes differ in axonal morphology/projections.  
- **Figure (from preprint):**  
  ![eLife logo/figure](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/_next/static/media/elife-logo.2ab2ee88.svg)

---

### 5. **Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy** (2024; preprint / eLife)
- **Published:** Reviewed preprint (updated Nov 26, 2024; Version of Record Jan 20, 2026) — eLife  
- **Link:** [Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/99688v2)  
- **Summary:** Large collaborative effort (Blue Brain / related teams) describing anatomical data used for detailed neocortical micro- and mesocircuit models — extensive morphological and connectivity data relevant to cerebral circuit modeling.  
- **Figure (from preprint):**  
  ![eLife logo/figure](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/_next/static/media/elife-logo.2ab2ee88.svg)

---

## Would you like:
- Full-text retrieval for any of these papers? I can attempt to read the full articles (if publicly available) using the read-paper tool.  
- A focused list restricted to a subregion of the cerebrum (e.g., prefrontal cortex, visual cortex, somatosensory cortex)?  
- Links to associated neuron morphology datasets (reconstructions / SWC files) when available?

If you tell me which option you prefer, I’ll proceed.

**Description:**

me_model_glossary.ai_response:
I'll look up the platform glossary for the definition of \ME-model.\I'll try searching the product documentation for \ME-model".I'll list documentation entries to search for definitions.## Definition — What is an **ME-model**?

**ME-model** stands for **Morphological Electric model**.  
**ME-models** are integrated neuron models that combine a cell's morphological reconstruction (shape/compartments) with its electrophysiological model (ion-channel / membrane dynamics) and are prepared to run in simulations. In platform terminology: **ME-models are models that are ready to be simulated.**

### Key components
- **Morphology** — reconstructed neuronal structure (soma, dendrites, axon) with compartmental geometry.  
- **Electrical model (e-model)** — the biophysical description of membrane properties and ion channels (conductances, kinetics, passive properties).  
- Optionally, **synaptic mechanisms** or connection descriptions when the ME-model is used in network contexts.

### Primary use
- Single-cell simulations (biophysically-detailed), where morphology and electrophysiology are required together to produce realistic voltage traces, spike initiation, and subcellular responses.
- ME-models serve as the unit for running both standalone single-cell experiments and as the biophysical neuron elements in circuit simulations.

If you want, I can:
- List ME-models available in the database for a species or brain region, or
- Retrieve a specific ME-model by ID to show its metadata and files. Which would you like me to do next?

software_docs_obione.user: Please show me a code example of how to create a single cell simulation using the obione package.
software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

If you want, I can:
- provide a minimal runnable script adjusted to your environment (if you give me the MEModel ID and where your db_client/config is stored),
- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?
software_docs_obione.ai_response:
## Single-cell simulation example (Python, obione)

Below is a practical, well-organized example that shows the typical steps for creating and running a single-cell simulation with the obione client library. It demonstrates: creating a simulation object, selecting a morphology and electrophysiological model (EModel), configuring initialization and stimuli, recording membrane voltage, running the simulation, and retrieving results.

Note: obione package APIs can evolve. Treat this as a clear, idiomatic example — adapt field names and function calls to the exact obione version in your environment or ask me to fetch the current documentation.

### Example: run a single-cell simulation and plot Vm

```python
# Example: single_cell_simulation.py
# Requires: obione, numpy, matplotlib (or plotly)
# Install (if available): pip install obione numpy matplotlib

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from obione import ObioneClient        # replace with actual import path if different
from obione.models import (
    SingleCellSimulationConfig,       # high-level config dataclass / builder
    StimulusCurrentStep,
    RecordingConfig,
    MorphologyRef,
    EModelRef,
)

# 1) Create API client (authenticate as required)
client = ObioneClient(api_token=\YOUR_API_TOKEN")  # or other auth method

# 2) Build single-cell simulation configuration
sim_config = SingleCellSimulationConfig(
    name=\SingleCell: step current test",
    description=\Inject a 200 pA step current to soma, record soma Vm",
    # reference existing morphology and e-model by ID or name
    morphology=MorphologyRef(id=\morph-uuid-or-name"),
    emodel=EModelRef(id=\emodel-uuid-or-name"),
    initialize={
        \v_init": -70.0,              # initial membrane potential (mV)
        \extracellular_calcium_concentration": 1.2,  # mM (example)
        andom_seed": 1234
    },
    simulation_length_ms=500.0,       # total simulation length (ms)
    dt_ms=0.025                       # simulation timestep (ms)
)

# 3) Define stimuli (current clamp)
step_stim = StimulusCurrentStep(
    target_location=\soma",          # e.g., \soma\ or node-set name; adapt to API
    start_time_ms=100.0,
    duration_ms=200.0,
    amplitude_pA=200.0               # picoamps
)

sim_config.stimuli = [step_stim]

# 4) Define recordings
rec_soma = RecordingConfig(
    record_target=\soma",            # e.g., soma compartment or node-set
    variables=[\v"],                 # membrane potential
    sample_interval_ms=0.1
)
sim_config.recordings = [rec_soma]

# 5) Create the simulation on the platform (register/configure)
simulation = client.single_cell.create_simulation(sim_config)
# simulation will contain an id and the resolved simulation resource

# 6) Run the simulation (synchronously or async)
# Synchronous run (blocks until finished)
result = client.single_cell.run_simulation(simulation.id, wait=True)

# 7) Retrieve recorded traces (the API might return as arrays or as downloadable files)
# Example: result.recordings is a dict with arrays
t = result.recordings[\soma"][	ime_ms"]      # time vector (ms)
vm = result.recordings[\soma"][\v"]            # membrane potential (mV)

# 8) Simple plot (matplotlib)
plt.figure(figsize=(8,3.5))
plt.plot(t, vm, color=\C0")
plt.xlabel(\Time (ms)")
plt.ylabel(\Vm (mV)")
plt.title(\Single-cell Vm: step current injection (200 pA)")
plt.axvspan(100, 300, color=\orange", alpha=0.15, label=\stimulus")
plt.legend()
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

# 9) Optional: save results locally
np.savez(\single_cell_step_result.npz", time_ms=t, vm=vm)
```

### Explanations / mapping
- Authenticate with your obione credentials or token when creating the client.
- Morphology and EModel references typically point to existing platform entities (use UUIDs or human-readable names depending on the API).
- Initialization parameters: v_init, extracellular calcium, random seed — set physiological defaults as needed.
- Stimuli: current-clamp (step) is illustrated. You can add other stimulus types (noisy current, synaptic conductance) if supported.
- Recordings: choose what variables (v, ionic currents, spikes) and sampling interval.
- Running: some deployments support asynchronous runs with an execution id and polling; others allow blocking runs that return results directly.
- Results: API may return traces in-memory or provide downloadable files (SONATA, HDF5, JSON). Adapt retrieval code accordingly.

### Next steps I can help with
- Fetch the exact obione API reference for your installed version so we can adapt the code to precise class/method names.
- Provide an example that records multiple compartments, or uses synaptic stimuli.
- Convert plotting to Plotly for interactive figures (I can run code and display a Plotly figure if you want).

Would you like me to fetch the current obione single-cell documentation pages or generate runnable code that uses the platform REST endpoints for your account?
